title: wear face mask home stop spread coronavirus household
story: FACE masks should be worn at home to stop the spread of coronavirus through households, scientists say.The Government urged Brits to wear face coverings in public spaces - where social distancing isn’t possible - to prevent the spread of Covid- earlier this month.However, researchers in China say face masks should now also be worn at home to help ward off the spread of Covid- infection among family members living under the same roof.They say that this practice is  per cent effective at curbing coronavirus transmission through households - but only before symptoms emerge in the first person infected.The researchers made the recommendation after questioning  people from  families in Beijing, China, on their household hygiene and behaviours during the pandemic.Each family had at least one laboratory confirmed case of Covid- infection between late February and late March .The average family size was four, but ranged from two to nine, and was usually made up of three generations.Family members were defined as those who had lived with the infected person for four days before and more than  hours after that persons symptoms first appeared.The researchers wanted to know what factors might heighten or lessen the risk of subsequently catching the virus within the incubation period -  days from the start of that persons symptoms.During this time, secondary transmission - spread from the first infected person to other family members - occurred in  out of the  families.A total of  adults and children were infected in this way, giving an attack rate of  per cent or around one in four.Around a third of the study children caught the viruscompared with more than two thirds of the adults .Twelve of the children had mild symptoms one had none. Mostof the adults had mild symptoms in around one in ten, symptoms were severe, and one person became critically ill.Daily use of disinfectants, window opening, and keeping at least one metre apart were associated with a lower risk of passing on the virus, even in more crowded households.However, in particular, the researchers noted that a face mask worn before symptoms started was  per cent effective, and disinfection  per cent effective, at stopping the virus from being passed on.The authors acknowledge some limitations to their study, which was published in BMJ Global Health, as telephone interviews are subject to recall and the strength of household disinfectants and bleach used wasnt recorded.Despite this, they suggest the findings back universal face mask use, not just in public spaces, but also at home.And the findings may also be relevant for families living with someone in quarantine or in enforced social isolation, and for the families of health workers who may face an ongoing risk of infection, they say.This study confirms the highest risk of household transmission being prior to symptom onset, but that precautionary [non-pharmaceutical interventions], such as mask use, disinfection and social distancing in households can prevent Covid- transmission during the pandemic, independent of household size or crowding, they write.Household transmission is a major driver of epidemic growth, they point out, adding that their findings could be used to inform precautionary guidelines for families to reduce intrafamilial transmission in areas where there is high community transmission or other risk factors for Covid-.Despite this, Professor Trish Greenhalgh, Professor of Primary Health Care Services at the University of Oxford, says the researchers findings must be weighed against the practicalities and the absolute risks involved.She said: In localities where the incidence of Covid- is high, people might feel this measure is worth the inconvenience, especiallythere is a vulnerable family member.Where the incidence of the disease is low, the balance between benefits and hassles may lean more towards the latter.Currently, the World Health Organizationhavent endorsed the wearing of face masks indoors or outdoors, on the grounds that theres little good quality evidence to warrant recommending this.Earlier this month, Brits were told to wear face coverings in public to prevent the spread of coronavirus.Boris Johnson said that homemade masks should be worn in enclosed spaces where social distancing isn’t possible or where you may come into contact with people from outside of your household.It includes public transport and in some shops, the Prime Ministers -page roadmap to get the UK out of lockdown revealed.The Department of Health said that after considering the latest scientic advice from Sage, face coverings can help reduce the spread of Covid-.They stressed that the evidence shows face coverings can stop you passing coronavirus on to others,you are asymptomatic or have yet to develop symptoms.Its unlikely they will stop you catching the bug.TfL also said all passengers and staff would need to wear masks on the Underground, and advised people avoided busy times.No  stressed that face coverings could include scarves and homemade masks - and added surgical masks used as vital PPE should be left for NHS and healthcare workers.The guidelines state that children under the age of two should not wear masks, nor should anyone who may find it dficult to manage them safely. This includes primary age children and those with respiratory conditions.The Government also warned that for face coverings to be effective, people must wash their hands before putting them on and taking them off.They added that masks arent necessaryyoure outside, while exercising, at schools or in offices.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: can use toilet friends family england
story: PEOPLE will be able to nip into other peoples homes to use the loo when visiting friends or family, it was confirmed tonight.As Boris Johnson announced an easing of Englands lockdown rules, this afternoon it will mean groups of up to six can hang out together in gardens or parks.But as many public toilets remain firmly shut, many feared where they would be allowed to take a small break when visiting pals and family outdoors.Tonight it was confirmed that people will be allowed to nip into a friend or neighbours home to use the loo while out on a trip.It will be the first time that the public will be permitted to go into another persons home since the lockdown was announced on March .Exceptions to this rule were made for emergency repairs, cleaners or childcare like nannies.But this is the first time it will apply to everyone.The news will delight members of the public hoping to go on a longer trip across the country to see friends and family.But they will be expected to not stay in someone s home for an extended period of time.Professor Chris Whitty said tonight: If someone was to go into the loo, it is absolutely critical that they wipe everything down, wash their hands all the way through.He said it was vital to keep good hygienepeople were going to start seeing each other again.Elsewhere in Boris Johnsons address to the nation tonight, he confirmed:However, the rules will be dferent in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as they continue to take slightly dferent approaches.Scotland will be allowed to meet in groups of up to eight people from tomorrow - but Englands guidance will be slightly dferent.A Downing Street spokesperson said earlier: This afternoon the Prime Minister had a call with the First Ministers of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as well as the deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland.“The PM made clear that as we begin to move to the next phase of tackling this virus, he remains determined to work closely with the devolved administrations. from dferent households and small team sports will be allowed to restart as lockdown restrictions are slowly eased.The move to allow multiple people from dferent households to meet up again - as long as they are socially distanced - comes after Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said eight people can meet upthey are only from two households.England has previously only allowed two people from dferent households to see one another.Mr Johnson announced the five crucial tests for lting lockdown had now been met and the UK would move to alert level .The nation has been at level  for the past two months.Mr Johnson said this evening: These changes mean that friends and family can start to meet their loved ones perhaps seeing both parents at once or both grandparents at once.For many people I know this will be a long awaited and joyful moment. We know the transmission of the virus is far lower outdoors so we can confidently allow more interaction outside.Boris Johnson revealed this title: lockdown rules different england scotland wales
story: THE RELAXATION of lockdown restrictions has caused fractures within the UK as Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland refused to follow Boris Johnsons roadmap.Nicola Sturgeon announced today Scotland would see the first easing of draconian measures tomorrow - two weeks after the PM relaxed rules in England.Mr Johnson has been adamant the UK should be united in its approach to lting lockdown, but devolved administrations refused to follow suit after he announced people in England could spend unlimited time outdoors and begin to see friends and family again.The Prime Minister announced today the crucial five tests for lting lockdown had been met and England would move to alert level  - after being at alert level  for two months.Boris Johnson revealed this evening:In a call with the First Ministers from Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland Mr Johnson made clear relaxing lockdown is a UK-wide approach evendferent areas may travel at slightly dferent speeds.A Downing street spokesman said:stressed the importance of particularly close engagement on programmes that must be UK-wide to be most effective.“ agreed that continued engagement is vital and that they will remain in close contact in the days and weeks ahead.”People in England are now able to meet up to six other people from dferent households in outdoor spaces and private gardens - and they are allowed to go through peoples homes to get to gardens and use their toilets.Ms Sturgeon warned Scots today they could see people in groups of up to eight - but only two households could see one another.She also said they should not use each others toilets and to be mindful of that when travelling to see people.In Wales, people are not allowed to meet up with other households.In Northern Ireland groups of four to six people who are not part of the same household can gather outdoors as long as they are socially distanced.In England, people have been allowed to spend an unlimited amount of time outdoors for the last three weeks.They have been allowed to have picnics, sunbathe and travel to beauty spots and beaches - no matter how far away they have been.Scotland and Wales both kept stay-at-home orders in place as the PM moved to the Stay Alert messaging.That was relaxed somewhat in Scotland today - people can spend leisure time outdoors, but should stay local, within a  mile radius of their home.Ms Sturgeon urged people not to travel to beauty spots and tourist destinations eventhey were nearby, because of the risk of crowds spreading coronavirus.People in Wales can exercise more than once a day - but non-essential travel is still banned.Schools in England will reopen for pupils in reception, year one and year six from Monday June .Class sizes will be limited to  pupils and strict social distancing measures will be introduced in classrooms.All Scottish students willto classrooms on August , with a mix of home learning and in-school teaching to make sure there arent too many people in schools.Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford has said he does want to get some kids back in classrooms before the summer break - but that they wont open on June .Northern Ireland has pushed the schools reopening date back even further - with a phased reopening in August or September.All non-essential retail has remained closed throughout the United Kingdom.Gardens centres are now open in England and Northern Ireland.They will be allowed to reopen in Scotland from next week.From June , non-essential retail in England will be allowed to reopen the Prime Minister title: france burned facemasks coronavirus ppe shortage
story: FRANCE burned .billion face masks before the coronavirus pandemic as it was thought they wouldn’t be needed, it was reported.The country has seen  doctors die from Covid  and they are among the hundreds of medics around the world who have died from the disease, amid a shortage of Personal Protective Equipment.At one point France had as stock pile of a billion surgical masks and  million high-performance FFP masks, which filter  per cent of particles, in preparation for and outbreak of swineflu or SARS.But when it was found that these diseases were less deadly that had been thought, the decision was made to burn them, The Times reports.When the coronavirus struck France, it was found that only  million masks remained.The scandal has seen President Emmanuel Macrons popularity plummeting.Jean-Paul Hamon, Chairman of the Federation of Doctors of France, says he was told at a health ministry meeting in February that GPs were being equipped with FFP masks.But eight days after the meeting, officials called to say that GPs didnt need the masks and ordinary ones would be do - as long as patients also wore them.“The trouble was, there werent enough masks for patients. Thats when we started to think, Hey, ho! Somethings up here,” he said.The -year-old, who was among the  doctors infected and he said some of deaths of doctors have been reduced had more FFP masks been available.“Ministers lied when they said FFP masks werent necessary for GPs, and they lied again when they said there was no point in providing ordinary face masks for the general public,” he said.Pierre Giacometti, a leading pollster, said Macrons has been badly damaged,The handling of the masks has really damaged his image, he said.People have the impression that he didnt have a clear vision of what he was doing and tried to hide the truth from them.At least , health care workers across the globe have been infected with the coronavirus, a report earlier this month found,.Hundreds in the frontline in the battle against the disease have died as the result of a lack of PPE.The World Health Organisation said  million medical masks,  million gloves and . million goggles are needed per month but a lack of equipment was putting lives at risk.In Italy, at least  doctors were killed amid anger about a lack of protection.Head of Italian doctors association Filippo Anelli said: We can longer allow our doctors, our health workers, to be sent to fight without any protection against the virus. It is an unfair fight.”In the United States, to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, shows more than , health care workers have been infected and close to  have died from Covid-.But the National Nurses United said its own count shows more than  health care fatalities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: are public toilets open during the coronavius lockdown
story: As a result of the lockdown, public toilets across the country were forced to close its doors due to the health risks they pose.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMost public toilets, along with several aspects of public le, were forced to close due to the coronavirus lockdown.Some were made to shut down for hygienic reasons as hundreds of people could use the facilities in locations where they are in high demand.Should a single person infected with the virus access the facility, it could spread to infect several other people.However, there are some councils who have chosen to leave public toilets opened in the midst of the crisis.As a result of the closure of non-essential businesses, public toilets in restaurants, pubs and shopping centers have also closed.Some public toilets in Brighton and Bournemouth have began to open their doors to the public.The National Trust has also gone to say they will open their public toilets where possible at parks.It is vital to check with your local authorities whether public toilets are openedyou are planning to spend extended time outside.Although the government has outlined its roadmap to usher Britiain back to normality, there has been no mention of public toilets.With the reopening of facilities, however,  it may be only a matter of time before public toilets across the country follow suit.Experts have spoken out against the reopening with public toilets as they are seen as hotspots for the disease.According to Parks for London: Currently most London Boroughs will be keeping public toilets closed.There are several reasons public toilets could be high risks when it comes to coronavirus.Door handles can be a hub for the virus, with hundreds of people touching them at some of the most popular locations such as Londons Hyde Park.Taps can also pose a threat as after washing hands, people may have to close them with clean hands, thereby opening the possibility of infection.Queues to access the facilities also contribute to the risk factors when Public Health England guidelines on social distancing are not followed.Peter Collington, an infectious diseases and microbiology title: nissan keeps sunderland plant open
story: The Spanish government today vowed to get the car-maker to reverse the move, as workers burned tyres and shouted war outside the plant in Catalonia.The furious protests came after Nissan announced it had decided to centre European production at its UK plant in Sunderland and close the plant in Barcelona - which has around , workers.The Government, which said in January after meeting officials from the Renault-Nissan alliance that jobs at the plant were guaranteed, criticised the decision and urged Nissan to look at other options.Foreign Minister Arancha Gonzalez Laya said: We regret it and will do everything we can to overturn it.She said the government could talk to other players about the plant and insisted Spain has attractive assets for any business willing to manufacture cars.The Catalan regional government also begged Nissan to reconsider its decision and said it had offered the carmaker a million euro aid package.The company also said it will shut its factory in Indonesia, following four years of tumbling profits and a net loss of £billion in the last financial year. A spokesman said: Europe will remain an important part of Nissans global business. We have more than three decades of history in Europe, where Nissan created the crossover segment and took the lead in the rollout of electric vehicles and charging infrastructure.They added: Sunderland remains an important part of our plans for the European business.The new Juke was recently launched, and the plant is now preparing for the arrival of the new Qashqai.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain visa hong kong china security laws
story: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said the UK would change the status of British national overseaspassport holders, allowing them to stay longer and even take citizenship.Chinas rubber stamp parliament has voted to go forward with national security legislation for Hong Kong, prompting huge protests in the territory.The new law bans treason, calling for secession, sedition and subversion and could allow mainland security agencies to be set up in Hong Kong, sparking fears Chinese agents could arrest pro-democracy activists.Mr Raab said BNO passport holders are currently only allowed to stay in the UK for six months.“If China continues down this path and implements this national security legislation, we will change that status,” he said.“And we will remove that six-month limit and allow those BNO passport holders to come to the UK and to apply to work and study for extendable periods of  months and that will itself provide a pathway to future citizenship.”The British flag was lowered over Hong Kong when the colony was handed back to China in  after more than  years of British rule.But there have been fears its autonomy, guaranteed under the one country, two systems principle, is being eroded.Last year a proposed new extradition law to the mainland saw huge protests and calls then for Hong Kongers with BNO passports to be allowed to settle in the UK.The decision by Mr Raab comes as he and the foreign ministers of the United States, Canada and Australia said in a joint statement the proposed law would curtail the Hong Kong people’s liberties.Hong Kong has flourished as a bastion of freedom, the four countries said in a joint statement expressing their deep concern over Beijings move.The security law would curtail the Hong Kong peoples liberties, and in doing so, dramatically erode Hong Kongs autonomy and the system that made it so prosperous, they said.The statement comes after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he no longer regards Hong Kong as being autonomous.In Hong Kong itself, police fired tear gas and water cannons at protesters in as thousands took to the streets.China says the legislation will aim to tackle secession, subversion, terrorism and foreign interference in the city and insists it won’t harm Hong Kong’s autonomy.Foreign Minister Wang Yi said Hong Kong affairs were an internal matter for China, and that no external interference will be tolerated.Excessive unlawful foreign meddling in Hong Kong affairs has placed Chinas national security in serious jeopardy, he said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on title: time top football stars come out
story: AT least seven professional footballers – two Premier League stars among them – are trapped in the metaphorical closet because they are too terried to come out as gay.It’s a shameful reality that a lack of crowds at games because of the coronavirus crisis, possibly for many months to come, might provide these players a safer window of opportunity to reveal their sexuality.But how is it even possible that football grounds in  remain so toxic that not one playing pro has said they are gay since the late great Justin Fashanu in .While some footballers are prepared to be honest about who they are with close friends and even team-mates, none of them want to face the wrath of being “number one”.Becoming the first openly gay footballer of the modern era in Britain is a burden they simply cannot bear.The moment must come soon though and that’s why I am heartened that Justin’s campaigning niece Amal has been invited to work with the Professional Football Association on the issue that has for too long been swept under the carpet.However, I also understand why it’s unconscionable for any young man to put themselves through such scrutiny and homophobic abuse out of choice.I know how damaging such an environment can be. Every day I walked down the corridor of my high school in New Zealand to that sort of abuse. “F***ing faggot.” “You poofter.” “Bum boy.” You can imagine.I became prepared for it and engineered a steely exterior. But each incident made it harder for me to be the person I knew I wanted to be and even more aware I was an outsider in a world where straight men dominate.While attitudes are thankfully changing, they still extend across many industries.One of my early bosses in newspapers told me recently that an editor had resisted hiring “the poof” .Luckily, that boss — a mentor during my career who happens to be straight — held firm and didn’t accept such blatant homophobia.I’m never one to moan about a lack of ersity or embrace identity politics — all minorities have to fight to overcome stereotypes. Taking on a victim mentality doesn’t help, which is why I never have.But it’s far too simplistic to look at Queer Eye, Graham Norton and Tom Daley then declare homophobia doesn’t strangle careers even now.That said, Adrian Chiles’ illuminating interview in The Sun this week with Luke Tuffs, who came out as a teenage player at Camberley Town in Surrey, provides reason for hope.Now manager of Ashford Town, he revealed that when he first told his team-mates in a drunken moment of madness they were “absolutely cool” about his sexuality. Of course, there’s “savage” banter in the “un-PC” dressing rooms but he explained: “I don’t think it comes from malice — it comes from love.”In fact, I’d hazard a guess the banter would be just as brutala player had ginger hair, an overweight girlfriend or a small willy. Banter is a prized part of British le and must not be wiped out by the snowflake brigade. It’s very dferent to abuse.The closeted players should also look to Phillip Schofield’s coming out announcement. What the This Morning host probably believed was going to be a le-changing event, dominating his every waking moment, has now been largely shrugged off. It was a damp squib in the best possible way.Sure, Phillip is gay. But he’s still hosting This Morning with Holly and that’s what people talk about. We don’t care who he is sleeping with.It is, of course, a deeply personal choice, but I would encourage footballers living miserably in the closet to try to change the way they think about coming out. Being the first will give them an opportunity no one  will ever have.While some archaic football fans may not be ready for it, I genuinely believe the vast majority of the country and our culture truly is.The opportunities will be limitless. The love will be overwhelming.Thirty years of fear will be turned on its head. We just need one brave announcement.Andwe’re not careful the red tape and draconian restrictions will kill off an already struggling high street.Take shoe shops, where staff will have to quarantine any footwear tried on for  hours.If you’ve worked in retail you’ll know how damn impractical that is.And,we’re being guided by the science, who the heck has ever contracted coronavirus via their toes while wearing socks Clothes shoppers will not be able to try on items in a changing room. Why not just order on Amazon then Estimates suggest these corona-ready measures will also cost companies. A lot. To the tune of £, a store, according to one estimate.Making the shopping experience miserable for retailers and customers won’t help save our economy, given recovery requires people wanting to go out and spend.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gym reopen limit spread coronavirus
story: GYMS could safely reopenmanagers take steps to reduce members’ risk of catching coronavirus, experts say.Prof Henning Wackerhage, who has advised European officials, said the benefits of exercise outweigh the risk.Measures include opening windows, leaving  minute breaks between exercise classes and avoiding overcrowding.Instructors should wear microphone headsets and speak less and quieter to limit the spray of germs around studios.Bosses should also keep a list of when people trained to aid contact tracing, he added.Prof Wakerhage, Professor of Sports Biology at the Technical University of Munich, said: “Now its time to use the positive effects of sport whileBut the boffin warned high intensity classes, such as spinning, HIIT and Zumba, should remain banned indoors.This is because the energetic workouts make people breathe harder and turn them into “virus slingshots”, he claimed.Additional measures include wiping down weights and equipment after use and using air ventilation systems.Prof Wakerhage added: “There is evidence that regular exercise reduces the severity of infections.“With measures… one can once again do sports with a clear conscience.”Gyms have reopened in some parts of Germany but remain closed in the UK.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: water company showers bath hosepipe ban
story: Yorkshire Water also wants its million households to turn off taps when brushing teeth.The supplier has seen a spike in demand amid lockdown and one of the driest springs since records began in .Temperatures are set to hit Ftoday — the hottest day of the year so far — and Ftomorrow.Yorkshire Water said: “This good weather has meant the levels in our reservoirs are lower than they normally would be.”Asking households to voluntarily cut usage is a first option for water firms.If that fails to ease the pressure, they can apply to the Environment Agency for a hosepipe ban.South East Water has also asked its .million customers to cut usage.United Utilities, which serves seven million homes, has applied for a drought order to sustain supplies in West Cumbria.The East and North East have seen only .in of rain in three months.This month is expected to be England’s driest May since . title: post lockdown wetherspoons future britains pubs
story: HOPES are high pubs will reopen soon — and The Sun has been given a sneak peek at how they will look.Boris Johnson raised spirits when he announced bars could be back in business in weeks and hinted the two-metre gap rule for punters may be halved.Pub bosses welcomed the move — which would put the UK in line with other countries and advice from the World Health Organisation.It came as Wetherspoons unveiled £million plans to overhaul its  boozers to make them Covid safe.We were allowed in the prototype pub the Mossy Well in Muswell Hill, North London.The only problems were health and safety rules meant there was no beer being served — and only myself and a photographer were allowed in.So I posed in ious locations to help show how things would look when customers .Wetherspoons was keen to point out things would still be fine-tuned in the run-up to opening but I got a real feel for what it would be like.In typically roomy Wetherspoons pubs I can see it working until we get a vaccine.It will be even easierthey have a beer garden.And when the PM gives ’Spoons and others the green light to open — probably in June and not the originally pencilled-in date of July  — I will be there with a pint and, hopefully, a curry.Wetherspoons spokesman Eddie Gershon said: “We have worked tirelessly. Our initial investment will ensure our pubs will be safe for staff and customers.“Our pubs might look a bit dferent when they reopen, but they will be as welcoming as ever.”Today, Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association, said more than three quarters of pubs could reopen right awaysocial distancing rules were relaxed.If they stay at two metres, it will restrict it to just one in three.She added: “It is an internationally recognised standard of one metre, used in France, Italy and Denmark, which allows some kind of normality.“Pubs are currently on a very highly tuned Government le-support machine.“The longer they remain on it, and with all the other medicines they have to pay for, some won’t survive.“Once pubs close they are very, very hard to resuscitate.”Miss McClarkin added that, unless there was a national reopening, about  per cent of her members thought they would be out of business by September.Meanwhile a survey by Budweiser found more than nine in ten Brits could not wait to pop to a pub again, with more than a third eager toin the first week of reopening.They expect to spend an average of £ on their first visit.However, concerns do remain.More than half of pub-goers want a switch from queuing at the bar to table service and half would rather go to a pub that allowed them to order from their table using an app to reduce contact.Four in ten think staff should have to wear face masks and a similar proportion want plastic screens at the bar.Two thirds say they are much more likely to visithand sanitiser is readily available and a quarter plan to steer clear of the toilets altogether.Others will avoid visiting at peak times and half want to see numbers of customers limited.Paula Lindenberg, president of Budweiser Brewing Group, said: “It’s great to see so many Brits yearning to get back to the pub, even within the first week of them re-opening.“But it’s not without its cautions as the research found pubgoer’s behaviours, values and expectations will sht as lockdown eases.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus title: christian cooper amy central park new york city
story: Amy Cooper, no relation, would later lose her job with an investment management company.Christian Cooper, , attended Hard and previously worked as an editor for Marvel Comics.He is an avid bird watcher, an interest that spawned on Long Island when he was a child, according to The New York Times.It was his passion for birds and nature that led him to ask Amy Cooper to put her cocker spaniel on a leash during the confrontation on Monday.Christian told her that having a dog on a leash is required by law in The Ramble area of the New York City park.Amy refused his request.“Look,you’re going to do what you want, I’m going to do what I want, but you’re not going to like it,” he told her, according to The Times.Christian pulled out dog treats and began to film the dispute.Please stop, sir Im asking you to stop recording me, Amy can be heard saying.Im going to tell [the police] theres an African-American man threatening my le, she adds.Christian responds: Please, tell them whatever you like.Amy is seen backing away from the man as she follows through on her vow.Theres a man, an African-American, hes recording and threatening me and my dog, she told the dispatcher.Amy Cooper, who served as head of insurance investment solutions for Franklin Templeton until recently, has apologized.The police responded to her call on Monday and found that two iniduals had engaged in a verbal dispute, according to The Times.I reacted emotionally and made  assumptions about his intentions when, in fact, I was the one who was acting inappropriately by not having my dog on a leash, she wrote in a public apology.When Chris began offering treats to my dog and confronted me in an area where there was no one  nearby and said, Youre not going to like what Im going to do next, I assumed we were being threatened when all he had intended to do was record our encounter on his phone.He had every right to request that I leash my dog in an area where it was required.I am well aware of the pain that misassumptions and insensitive statements about race cause and would never have imagined that I would be involved in the type of incident that occurred with Chris.I hope that a few mortying seconds in a letime of forty years will not define me in his eyes and that he will accept my sincere apology.She said her le was being destroyed after video of the incident went viral.It has also been revealed that she once accused an ex-lover of cheating her out of , she had paid him to leave his abusive we.Franklin Templeton said Tuesday that we do not tolerate racism of any kind.Following our internal review of the incident in Central Park yesterday, we have made the decision to terminate the employee involved, effective immediately, the company said.Cooper ed the canine to the rescue group she had adopted him from a few years before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: firms wages staff isolate track trace
story: EMPLOYERS will be urged to cover the wages of staff told to self isolate under the track and trace system.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said it is very important employers are flexible around this as the TUC union called for an increase in sick pay to stop people ignoring their civic duty to isolate.The fears come that low paid workers, and the self-employed will not self-isolate when they are not symptomatic and will still go to work. Some employers may force their workers to take the isolation time as holiday.No said that there was “already signicant financial support available” to the self employed, and that in some cases they could claim universal credit and unemployment support allowance.A Downing Street spokesman said: “We’ve had a scheme in place during the lockdown and that means there is signicant financial support available.”They added: “If an employee is not sick and can work from home they should do so as normal.“Statutory sick pay is available to those who have been contacted by the test and trace service and are unable to work as a result, and of course some employers will continue to offer their own sickness policies and offer full pay for all or some of the inidual’s isolation period.”But the Test and Trace system will fail to work effectivelystatutory sick pay is not increased unions have warned.TUC general secretary Frances OGrady said: “It will not be effectiveworkers are pushed into hardship when they are required to self-isolate.Statutory sick pay is just £ per week - and two million workers arent even eligible for that. If workers cant afford to self-isolate, then they will be forced to keep working. That will put them, their workmates and their local community at risk, and undermine the entire Test and Trace programme.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth also called for enhanced sick pay when he was asked about the new system and people being expected to self-isolate for  dayscontacted.He said: There will be people whose work conditions and employment conditions make that dficult for them so they need that security, they need enhanced sick pay where necessary to make sure they stay at home.But, of course, it is perfectly possible that you could isolate for  days, come out, meet somebody  again who has got the virus and have to go back in. So this could be a huge burden for people.Yesterday MPs were told that local levels of the system would not be ready to roll out until the end of June after a conference call with Tracing chief Dido Harding.Labour MP Ben Bradshaw said: “Dido Harding just told me on an MPs’ conference call that Test, Trace  Isolate won’t be fully operational at local level till the end of June.Not sure where that leaves Johnson’s promise of a fully operational “world beating” system by Monday.”But NHS Providers chief executive Chris Hopson said it was never going to be the case that the UK would have a world-class test and trace system in place on Monday.Mr Hopson said that while work on introducing the system was progressing at pace, the UK is weeks behind where we really ought to be.He said: There has been good progress, things are being put into place, but they are going to take time. Partly, to be frank, because we should have been doing quite a lot of these things months and weeks ago, and they werent being done.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. backbench Tory MPs have called for him to quit.MICHAEL studies at the Royal Agricultural University and shares a student house in Cirencester, Gloucs, with two others.He said: “We had friends round I don’t have any regrets. It was the best for myself and my hairdresser.”TOM, from London, says he has no regrets about inviting his girlfriend to his home for a dirty weekend.He said: “We were gagging to see each other. I feel guilty but I’m glad we did it.”MUM-of-three Emily, , travelled  miles to stay overnight with her dad, , after his twin brother died of the virus.The health and wellbeing adviser, of Oxford, said: “It was heartbreaking for my dad. title: cash help self employed extend
story: BORIS Johnson signalled tonight that crucial state aid for self-employed workers hit by the coronavirus crisis will be extended beyond this month.Grants worth up to £, to cover the last three months come to an end on Sunday and Rishi Sunak has so far failed to say whether he will extend the crucial leline to self-employed workers.In contrast, he has promised wage support for furloughed workers for an extra five months - until the end of October.But the Prime Minister told the daily coronavirus press conference that youll be hearing more about support for self-employed workers soon.Mr Johnson also promised self-employed people who are forced into two weeks quarantine as part of the new Test and Trace programme will receive financial compensation from loss of income.He said: Those who face temporarily losing their income as a result of this will be helped.Last night  MPs from all parties including a string of senior Tories signed a letter to the Chancellor demanding he extends the self-employment scheme.They warned that hundreds of thousands of self-employed people will be without work and without support from next week.Mr Sunak was said to be weighing up how to extend support for the self-employed as he faces breaking a key Boris Johnson pledge to offer “parity of support” for them as employees.A total of . million workers have now applied to the self-employment income support scheme at a cost of £. billion.Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh, who organised the letter, said: “This scheme is a leline for millions of locked-down workers right across the country.“There are already signicant holes in the support, but removing what is already in place would pull the safety net from under the feet of millions of self-employed workers.“How can it be right for the furloughed scheme to continue but this scheme to not ”The letter says: Whilst some of our self-employed constituents may be able toto work over the coming weeks and months, it remains likely that many will not. If the scheme does not continue, they will be left without work and without support.“We are calling on you to ensure that this scheme is continued and to provide details of an extension as soon as possible.”The Treasury said it was keeping the SEISS under review and pointed to Mr Sunaks words in March when he said the scheme could be extendednecessary.It said it was unfair to compare the self employment income support with the furlough scheme because self-employed people could still work while receiving grants. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new freedom allowed meet six relatives
story: From Monday, the Prime Minister has deemed it safe for us to meet up to six friends and relatives at a time — provided we follow social distancing rules and stay outdoors.It means grandparents will soon be allowed to see their beloved grand- children again. Hard-working parents will be able to call on extended family for childcare help.And young people starved of social contact can meet in the park for a picnic.Thanks to the phenomenal efforts of Brits up and down the country, we have protected the NHS, saved lives, and passed the first peak of the virus.Which is why our cherished liberties are now being ed to us, albeit slowly.Now, we must do everything in our power to avoid a second wave.Let’s not let the new freedoms go to our heads.IT’S clear that track and trace is key to beating this virus.South Korea — which tracked and traced properly from the start — recently had an outbreak caused by one man going to a series of nightclubs.The incident could have led to a second peak. But contact-tracers found more than , iniduals and managed to isolate more than  people infected by the super-spreader. Which is why the Government must iron out the wrinkles in our programme NOW.Yes, getting the system up and running from a standing start has been a challenge. We know that Asian countries — which learnt how to track and trace during the Sars and Mers epidemics — were at an advantage.But surely the best minds in this country are capable of developing glitch-free software.And is it too much to ask that our tracers are given rigorous training before they take our lives in their hands WE welcome news that the Government will allow British National residents of Hong Kong to stay in Britain for a yearBeijing goes ahead with its proposed new sanctions on anti-government protests.When the UK handed Hong Kong to the Chinese, Beijing promised “one country, two systems” with genuine democracy. But these promises were broken long ago. Now, pro-democracy, anti-Beijing protesters are openly manhandled by police on the streets of the city.It is absolutely right that we give these British passport-holders sanctuary.Welcoming them will prove that post-Brexit Britain is a truly global country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus vaccines available end year
story: SEVERAL coronavirus vaccines will be available by the end of this year, the world’s leading drugs companies suggested today.The upbeat message came as the pharmaceutical giants said they had set aside commercial rivalries to develop jabs together.Pascal Soriot, chief executive of AstraZeneca, said: “The hope of many people is that we will have a vaccine — hopefully several — before the end of this year.”His company is among members of the International Federation of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers  Associations working with universities and governments on vaccines.Ten potential vaccines are already in trials worldwide, including one from the University of Oxford.The IFPMA’s Thomas Cueni said: “We are in there together - and these companies will deliver.“We will find a vaccine or vaccines in collaboration and partnership.“I’m convinced with all the challenges, the question marks, the science will win. title: figures businesses six months cash reserves
story: FOUR in ten businesses in the UK have less than six months of cash reserves left, in an alarming sign of the looming economic crash.Only three in ten firms said they had cash reserves to cover beyond six months, while a quarter were unsure according to the latest Office for National Statistics survey on the impact of the coronavirus crisis on the economy.It also found that eight in ten companies in the UK have used the Governments wage support scheme.Around one in seven businesses that paused trading when lockdown was introduced in March said they are intending to restart trading in the next fortnight.But on average, only a third of their workforces are expected tofrom furlough leave.The job retention scheme currently sees the state paying  per cent of furloughed workers’ salaries.But from August, employers who continue to furlough workers will have to contribute  per cent of their wages and also pay towards their National Insurance employer contributions and pension contributions.Mr Sunak is expected to announce the details of how the job retention scheme will work beyond July over the next few days.Treasury figures released earlier this week revealed . million jobs are currently furloughed from  million employers, at a cost of £ billion to taxpayers.Mr Sunak has said firms will be allowed to furlough staff part-time from August.He could bring this flexibility in soonerindustries like pubs and restaurants are allowed to open earlier than expected.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: MATT Hancock yesterday sparked hopes Brits could soon be able to get their dodgy barnets trimmed at the hairdresser.Amid a growing clamour for salons to reopen, the Health Secretary said the challenge is not “insurmountable”.He refused to give a date for when barbers will be back up and running. title: ww2 plane shifting sands unearthed beach
story: The Bristol Beaufighter crash-landed shortly after take-off in April .The crew were uninjured but the maritime fighter stayed buried for decades.It was discovered at Cleethorpes in Lincs by local couple Graham Holden and Debi Hartley while walking their dog on Bank Holiday Monday.Graham said: I never expected to find anything like this in my le.“It’s an amazing find.I went out there just last week and it wasn’t there.”They photographed the wreckage and the RAF confirmed it was a Beaufighter from nearby war base North Coates.Graham said: “It could be covered up again soon for another  years.”Of almost , Beaufighters built during the war, there are believed to be only five complete versions in the world.The discovery comes weeks after the wreck of a car sunk on Cleethorpes beach  years ago was uncovered by moving sands.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But the official advice suggests that some people might prefer to use their holiday entitlement to cover the time at home. The official guidance reads: If people can’t work from home, employers must ensure any self-isolating employee is receiving sick pay and give them the option to use their paid leave daysthey prefer. There are fears that many workers will not be able to afford to isolate becuse statutory sick pay is just £ a week and millions of workers are not eligible for it. TUC general secretary Frances OaposGrady said: We need a testing and tracing programme up and running as soon as possible. But it will not be effectiveworkers are pushed into hardship when they are required to self-isolate. Statutory sick pay is just £ per week - and two million workers arenapost even eligible for that. If workers canapost afford to self-isolate, then they will be forced to keep working. That will put them, their workmates and their local community at risk, and undermine the entire Test and Trace programme.  The Government must extend statutory sick pay to everyone - no matter what theyaposre paid - and raise it to the level of the real Living Wage, £ per week. And the self-employed income support scheme must remain in place as a source of financial support for those forced to self-isolate. Thataposs how to show that we really are all in this together. Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth called for enhanced sick pay when he was asked about the new system and people being expected to self-isolate for  dayscontacted. Weaposve made sick pay more generous by starting it from day one and will refund employers with up to  staff the cost of up to two weeksapos sick pay.  Employers can, and many do, pay more than the statutory rate - something we encourage. Dame Gillian Guy, chief executive of Citizens Advice, said the Government must ensure people do not face a sudden drop in incomethey have to self-isolate under the Test and Trace system. She said: Problems with our system for sick pay are long-standing. Even for those eligible for statutory sick pay, it may not be enough to cover essential living costs. Seven out of  people want Downing Street lackey Dominic Cummings sacked after flagrantly breaching “stay at home” rules. They’re right, but they don’t go far enough. The real villain is not dastardly Dom. It is Boris Johnson. He put political and class loyalty to his Svengali “special adviser” ahead of the national interest. He has presided over the most chaotic, least successful, campaign against coronavirus in Europe. He scrapped test-and-trace in mid-March, and undermined the policy even before it restarted, confusing the population with mixed messages. Forget the monkey. It’s the organ grinder who is the guilty man. The Prime Minister should go, and take his numpty Cabinet accomplices with him. Weeks ago, I called them second rate. I was wrong. They’re fourth rate. It will not happen, of course, because boastful Bojo is sitting on a big Commons majority and political turkeys – not even wattle-quivering Tory MPs – do not vote for Christmas. More than  of them have urged Johnson to ditch his sickening sidekick. Some, like ambitious Jeremy Hunt, half-heartedly. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAfter spending so long setting up Britain Connects, I clicked with some trepidation on the link we’d generated at pm, the same time as hundreds of other people across the UK. Would it work  Would anyone be there  In a miracle of modern technology now familiar to families across the UK, a smiling face appeared, a little blurred by my wi signal. Raja Khan, a -year-old law student and entrepreneur. A Conservative voter and enthusiastic Leaver, to my Remain-voting, Labour member self. Our conversation began as all video calls must – “can you hear me ” Raja was  miles away in Leicester, living with his mum who had moved in with him so she wouldn’t be alone during lockdown. He was wearing a smart suit, after a day at work via zoom. I was in a t-shirt, full of euphoric relief that the thing had worked. To kick off, we tackled one of the questions set by the Behavioural Insights Team for Britain Connects. Who would we invite to a zoom dinner party and why  Raja went for Napoleon Hill, the Depression era author of ‘Think and Grow Rich’. I went for Nelson Mandela. So far so polarised. But I liked Raja’s second choice, Aldous Huxley. Raja wanted to ask the author what he made of our Brave New World. It’s one of my favourite books, and I’d have been fascinated to meet him. Born in Hong Kong, where some of his ancestors had arrived from India, Raja has a very global perspective.We had a fascinating chat about Brexit. Raja is studying EU law and is passionate about the lack of accountability in the way UK laws were governed from Brussels. He had even campaigned door to door for Leave in his local area. But he shared my concerns about racism during the time of the campaign and had even experienced it, “asthey hadn’t noticed Iaposm not white”. I’ve been as profoundly moved by this year’s project over Whereby – a videocall  – as I was by last year’s Britain Talks, where people were able to meet in person.For Britain Connects, some pairs matched by our  gave us the immense privilege of listening in to their meetings, giving us an extraordinary window through which to view people’s dfering experiences of the coronavirus. All of us are having very dferent experiences of the pandemic – whether we are key workers, working from home, home-schooling, furloughed, unemployed, shielding, young or old, too busy or too isolated. From accountants to zumba teachers, farmers to artists, this was a chance to hear about someone ’s unique experience of the last nine weeks. As Harish Sharma, , said to his match Janina Bacon: “Before this we wouldn’t have got involved in something like this. You don’t know me from Adam, I don’t know you - but here we are. I didn’t know what to expect… and it’s great.”  One of the interesting things about the project has been how many people have been prepared to talk about loneliness, and often not in ways we might expect. The loneliness of the nurse who spends days with intubated unconscious patients. The isolation of the supermarket worker behind glass, or the care-worker trapped behind a mask. And it has been moving to hear from disabled and elderly people, impacted by shielding to such a degree that many have seen no one for almost three months.  Diane Eubanks, , from urban Leeds, met Susan Wilkes,  from a rural village in Oxfordshire through Britain Connects. Diane voted Remain in the  referendum, while Susan voted Leave. Yet both shared very similar experiences of lockdown as shielding disabled women who live alone. Diane asked Susan, when she last felt lonely. “Probably most of the time since lockdown,” Susan said. “I usually meet friends for lunch every day. Recently I started to see a close friend of mine who is blind, so I can drop food items off for him from my own food parcels.” Afterwards Susan said she’d like to give Diane a hug. “I am so glad I have taken part in Britain Connects because I have made a new friend,” Diane said. “Can you hear me ” is the modern zoom phenomenon summed up. But it’s also how we all feel. We need to be heard by each other, and that also involves being able to listen. Of course, Raja and I already had one thing in common. We’d both been prepared to take a leap of faith into the unknown to meet each other. “The coronavirus is changing us,” Raja said. “Look at what we’re doing now. I would never have done this normally. I would love to do lots of these meetings and meet all kinds of people who are experiencing le and lockdown dferently. People need to meet people who are dferent. We need to come together somehow.”

up to six people will be permitted - so long as people from dferent households remain two metres away from each other.People will also be allowed to meet in gardens and other private outdoor spaces under certain conditions. The PM has said the five tests needed to ease the coronavirus lockdown have been met and up to six people will be allowed to meet outside from Monday. Schools are reopening from Monday in England. The PM confirmed all non-essential shops can reopen on June  - including those selling clothes and toys. But in a staggering press briefing, Johnson has drawn accusations of acting like Putin when faced with questions on Cummings. Follow our live blog below for the latest updates on the coronavirus pandemic in the UK and around the world. And sign up to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at mirror email -after the press conference every evening.Key EventsWhat pubs will look like post-lockdown with temperature checks and perspex screens:Dominic Cummings considers quitting later this year, according to reports:Millions of Brits applaud NHS heroes for what could be final Clap For Carers:BREAKING Dental practices in England to reopen from June  with strict rules:Boris Johnson accused of acting like Putin when faced with questions on Cummings::Thousands pay tribute to Covid- victims in online memorial bookThe Dean of St Paul#xs Cathedral has been #xCoverwhelmed#xD by the response of families and friends to the new online book of remembrance for Covid- victims.David Ison has led the project, called Remember Me, and said it was #xCincredibly moving#xD to see the tributes left with more than , names.The Prince of Wales gave his backing to the initiative when it was launched last Friday, saying the coronavirus outbreak had #xCbrought tragedy and heartbreak#xD for #xCtoo many#xD and the virtual book would help keep alive the memories of those who have died.The Dean said: #xCWe have been overwhelmed by the response to Remember Me. We were moved to start the project because so many people across the country were unable to say goodbye or mourn their loved ones in the usual ways.#xCIt has been incredibly moving to see the messages from family, friends and carers.#xCIt reminds us that every person who has died as a result of the Covid- pandemic is not merely a statistic in a health crisis - but a person, valued, missed and worthy of remembrance.#xDThe number of deaths involving Covid- in the UK is well over , according to the latest available data, with many dying in hospital alone and the numbers of mourners at funerals limited.The Dean and colleagues took just over five weeks to design and build an online portal where the bereaved of all faiths and none can #xCput that grief and that remembrance#xD.Family and friends have entered , names into the online book since it was officially opened on May .The Remember Me site will also become a physical memorial at St Paul#xs Cathedral, funds allowing, with designs approved for a new inner porch in the north transept.Relatives and friends of all those living in the UK who have died as a result of the Covid- pandemic can submit for free a name, photograph and a short message in honour of their loved one to the memorial website.The Dean of St Pauls Cathedral, David Ison :National Trust to reopen gardens - but you have to book in advanceThe National Trust is to begin opening gardens and parkland properties in England and Northern Ireland for people who have booked tickets in advance.The Royal Horticultural Societyis also reopening its four gardens around England with a pre-booked tickets system as rules around lockdown begin to ease.The moves come after the UK Government amended regulations to confirm that people in England could visit gardens and land maintained for public use, while, in Northern Ireland, the Executive permitted the reopening of outdoor spaces.The National Trust warned that all properties and car parks in Wales remain closed in line with Welsh Government rules.The phased reopening will begin with around  gardens and park properties opening from June , with only visitors who have booked in advance allowed entry to limit numbers and keep the public safe, the Trust said.More sites will open over the coming weeks for properties where social distancing can be observed, and with only around a third of the normal number of visitors permitted.All National Trust houses and shops remain closed, along with holiday cottages and campsites, and, while coastal and countryside car parks are mostly open, some busier ones may need to be closed or pre-booked, the charity said.Booking for parks and gardens opens on Friday morning on property web pages via the National Trust website, and will be free for Trust members, while other visitors will pay an admission fee.The charity, which said sites will be displaying information on how to stay safe and socially distanced, is also urging people to limit how many visits they book, stay localthey can, and avoid busy hot-spots.:KEY EVENTWhat pubs will look like post-lockdown with temperature checks and perspex screensPubs in Britain could be a far cry from their usual selves post-lockdown with temperature checks at the door, screens separating tables and no ordering at the bar.Manchester bar Albert#xs Schloss has revealed the measures it#xs putting in place to keep staff, customers and performers safe from Covid- when it is permitted to reopen.This could serve as a further indicator of what pubs and bars across the UK may look like in the coming months. The popular Peter Street venue has installed perspex screens between booths and at the bar, introduced a one-way system, removed tables and cut down its menu. The customer experience will be very dferent too - diners can either order and pay for their food through an app, or nominate what Albert#xs Schloss is calling a #xtable captain#x who will be given a disposable paper menu and pencil to fill out the party#xs orders.See all the pictures and read all about it HERE.A waiter wears a perspex visor :Tory MP took train from London to North East after displaying coronavirus symptomsA Tory MP has defended himself after he took a train from London to the North East of England while displaying coronavirus symptoms. Darlington MP Peter Gibson, part of the  intake of so-called Red Wall Tories, said he travelled  miles by train from the capital prior to lockdown to isolate at home. He made the comment on Facebook when posting about the Dominic Cummings scandal earlier this week.When asked why he had not stayed in London, he replied: #xCIt was several weeks before lockdown and at the time I had no London address.#xDRead the full story HERE. Darlington MP Peter Gibson:Fiona Bruce in fiery row with health minister over track and trace loopholesQuestion Time#xs Fiona Bruce had a fiery exchange with Health and Social Care Minister Helen Whately as she grilled her about #xloopholes#x in the Government#xs new track and trace system. The low-tech test, track and trace system which launched on Thursday could see healthy Brits forced to self-isolate for two weeks at homethey have been in contact with a confirmed case. Call handlers will interview those in England who have tested positive and ask for details of anyone they have recently been near.However, the app is not yet ready and a number of issues surround the scheme including what people will do about work and child care.These sparked a heated exchange during which Ms Whately began tripping over her words as Ms Bruce said: #xCFollow the guidance, unless you can#xt #xD in relation to looking after a childyou have to suddenly self-isolate.Read the full story HERE. :One in seven people may have broken lockdown rulesAround one in seven people may have broken lockdown rules by being visited at home by friends or family, research suggests.A study by King#xs College Londonwith Ipsos Mori found that members of the public claimed to be sticking to the now-altered #xCstay at home#xD advice to an #xCextraordinary degree#xD.But % of those surveyed said they have had home visits from friends or relatives during the lockdown - compared with % at the start of April.The researchers interviewed , people aged between  and  from May -, and compared some of the findings with a previous survey from April -.The poll was undertaken after the Government relaxed its #xCstay at home#xD guidance, instead adopting the slogan #xCstay alert#xD on May .And it closed on the day news first broke of political aide Dominic Cummings#x alleged lockdown breach after he travelled  miles to County Durham in March to self-isolate with his family.On Thursday, Boris Johnson announced that groups of up to six would be able to congregate in private gardens from Mondaythey stay two metres apart, but they cannot stay overnight or go indoors other than to access a garden.Prof Duffy said: #xCEven before the high-profile incident around Dominic Cummings, we had seen a decline in levels of trust and confidence in the Government over the six weeks, and that#xs partly related to the messages getting more complicated and confusing for people.#xCPeople are stuck quite firmly on the #xstay at home#x message and the #xstay alert#x message really hasn#xt got through in quite the same way, and that complexity as we slowly make our way out of this is only going to grow.#xDOne in seven may have broken lockdown rules :Renault poised to announce , layoffs worldwide amid coronavirusFrench carmaker Renault is poised to announce , layoffs worldwide on Friday as it unveils a plan to boost its profitability and cope with faltering sales, a representative for the CFDT union said after meeting with the company.Some , jobs would go in France, though largely through a voluntary departure plan and a retirement scheme, the CFDT#xs Franck Daout told Reuters on Thursday.The overall cuts would affect just under % of Renault#xs , global workforce. The firm has around , staff in France.#xCThey#xve insisted on the fact everything will be negotiated,#xD Daout said, adding that unions and state bodies would be involved in talks over potential job losses in France.Renault declined to comment. The carmaker#xs board signed off on the plans to launch its cost savings programme on Thursday, a source familiar with the matter said.The French group, which is % owned by the government, had earlier this year flagged a looming #xCno taboo#xD plan to cut  billion in costs after posting its first loss in a decade last year.That raised concern for some of its factories, including in France, although closures could be politically sensitive.Renault headquarters in Boulogne-Billancourt :Athlete praying for the best that Tokyo Olympics take place next yearFour-times Olympic champion Simone Biles said she was hopeful the rescheduled Tokyo Games will take place next year, amid concern over the global response to the novel coronavirus.#xCI#xm just praying for the best, hoping that it goes on - for selfish reasons, of course - but for all the athletes around the world working towards this dream,#xD said Biles, appearing at the virtual espnW Summit NYC. #xCBut then again you never know. If everybody#xs health is at risk, then obviously we shouldn#xt host it.#xDSenior international Olympic official John Coates said last week that Tokyo organisers face #xCreal problems#xD putting on the Games next year while Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has said the event cannot be postponed further.IOC Chief Thomas Bach said the Olympics would be scrappedthey cannot take place in July next year.Biles, the most decorated gymnast in world championship history, said she had ed to the gym this week after about seven or eight weeks away and was #xCgetting back into the swing of things#xD after the Olympic postponement had rattled her.#xCIt was hard to process, it didn#xt seem real le,#xD the -year-old American said, reflecting on the announcement two months ago. #xCIt was hard but then since the whole entire world was going through it at the same time, you didn#xt feel alone.#xDBiles, who won four gold medals at the  Rio Olympics including the all-around inidual title and the team event, also had to overcome doubts about her ability.#xCI still felt like, `Oh, can I do another year  I#xm getting pretty old. Will I be at the top of my game #x,#xD she said. #xCBut I know my coaches will prepare me.#xDSimone Biles :Liam Gallagher and Mark Owen lead Manchester doorstep singalongOasis singer Liam Gallagher, Take That#xs Mark Owen and James#x Tim Booth have helped to lead a virtual singalong for Manchester.The musicians introduced songs for the Together In One Voice event, which took place on Thursday. The one-off singalong aimed to unite Greater Manchester and celebrate the importance of community during the lockdown.The musicians introduced songs for viewers in pre-recorded clips for the livestreamed event.Singers Emeli Sande and Tom Walker and rapper Aitch also took part.Booth said that the song Sit Down by James, which he introduced, had a #xCpersonal#xD history for him.He said that his father-in-law had asked for him to sing the song via a video call #xCan hour before he died from this virus#xD.He added: #xCIt#xs a song of solidarity and hope in times of struggle.#xDGallagher introduced the Oasis song Wonderwall, which he called #xCthe mother of all singalongs#xD.Walker told viewers that #xCthe spirit and community and the sense of pride in Manchester is amazing#xD.He added: #xCIt is an honour that you guys have chosen to sing my song today.#xDThe YouTube livestream was viewed nearly , times.Liam Gallagher :Protection of publics health must be absolute priority in easing lockdown, expert saysResponding to the PM#xs announcement, British Medical Associationchairman Dr Chaand Nagpaul said: #xCThe protection of the public#xs health must be the absolute priority in easing lockdown with a health-driven strategy that does not result in the spread of infection or risk a spike in cases.#xCGiven what we now know about who is the most susceptible to Covid-, it is crucial that this strategy adequately protects the most vulnerable and at-risk in society and that the public adheres to the new social distancing measures.#xCThe new test and trace system is central to the easing of lockdown and as such, the Government must ensure that it has the capacity to meet demand. However, with a BMA survey revealing that less than a quarter of doctors are getting their results back within that time, with % waiting between four days and a week, accelerating this process must be a priority. It is also crucial that the data on the number of those tested is transparent and readily available.#xCImportantly, given the risk that many health and social care workers have faced in recent months with exposure to Covid-, we need assurances that they will have access to adequate PPE to carry out their work safely, particularlythere is a surge in demand. The mum said the Clap for Carers event left her children unable to sleep:KEY EVENTDominic Cummings considers quitting later this year, according to reportsBritish Prime Minister Boris Johnson#xs senior adviser, Dominic Cummings, is considering quitting later this year, the Daily Mail reports.Cummings, who faced calls from within the Conservative Party to resign for driving  milesduring the coronavirus lockdown, could be out in six months, the newspaper reported, citing sources.His trip from London to northern England was described by local police as a breach of the coronavirus lockdown but was also called by them as minor, thenewspaper had reported earlier on Thursday.Cummings#x behaviour has been criticised by politicians from all major parties, but Johnson has said he wanted to move on from the topic.Cummings, architect of the  campaign to leave the European Union, came under pressure when it was reported he had travelled from London to northern England in March when his we was ill with COVID- symptoms during a nationwide lockdown.He said on Monday that he had not offered his resignation. A #xCwake-up call#xD is needed to protect women#xs and children#xs rights amid the pandemic, said the president of Estonia and former prime minister of New Zealand who held a virtual summit with leaders from Canada, Costa Rica and Senegal and United Nations officials. #xCWe#xve all come together because none of us are prepared to stand by and see this pandemic erode the signicant progress that has been made on the health and rights of women and children and adolescents,#xD said Helen Clark, who served as prime minister of New Zealand from  to . #xCWe are hearing stories from the front lines of the immunizations not being able to be done, the pregnancy services not there, the sexual health and reproductive health services generally not there,#xD she told the Thomson Reuters Foundation. #xCIt doesn#xt have to be like this, but there#xs not currently enough global solidarity.#xD As vulnerable members of society, particularly in poorer countries, women are likely to take a big economic hit and have a hard time recoveringThe United Nations estimates the pandemic could cause  million unwanted pregnancies over the next six months as women lose access to contraception and reproductive health care. story: NewsCouple spend  years renovating dream home - then get nasty surpriseBarbara and Simon Campbell, of Grantham, Lincolnshire, now fear their Grade II-listed manor house could end up being virtually worthless despite their workShareCommentsByMartin Fricker:,  MAY NewsBarbara and Simon Campbell with daughters Meghan and Rosie " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA couple who spent  years restoring their th century home fear it could end up being virtually worthless – after plans were unveiled to build a quarry next door. Barbara and Simon Campbell bought the Grade II-listed manor house with  acres of land for £, in . Council bosses are now set to approve proposals for a quarry  yards away to extract a million tons of sand. Barbara, , and Simon, , may be powerless due to planning permission dating back more than  years. The mum and dad said they were not made aware of the authorisation when they bought the derelict building. Barbara said: “Everything has been hunky-dory… We then discovered the field next to us has dormant planning permission for a quarry. We couldn’t believe it. “The whole site has been covered by two planning applications, one dating back to  and the other from . “The fact this was effectively an existing quarry should have been ­available to us at the time we bought the property. It’s the unfairness and the lack of transparency that really galls us.”  The pair, who run an engineering firm and brought up their three kids, Megan and Rosie, both , and Alasdair, , in the house, are trying to stop the development, which they think may dramatically reduce the value of the property. They are also worried about possible health implications, such as cancer, feared to be caused by dust. They painstakingly renovated the six-bedroom home in Grantham, Lincolnshire. The land also has two lakes.

Troy House in Monmouth, which dates back to the th century had a guide price of £, - but a last-minute bidding war saw the cost swell to more than six times that figure.
